shortLinksItems.hed: The Best Way to Book a Last-Minute Valentine's Day Trip
shortLinksItems.dek: Custom travel specialist Henrietta Loyd says she can turn an itinerary around in 48 hours. Here's how. Plus, more insider wisdom.
shortLinksItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54cff6639abb8d533165d7dc]||||||





Spontaneous types, you’re in luck: It’s already February, but you can still book a Valentine’s Day getaway. “These days, people think much more last-minute than ever—I can turn an itinerary around in 48 hours,” says Henrietta Loyd, founder of the custom travel company __[Cazenove+Loyd](cazloyd.com)__. Since February is summer in the Southern Hemisphere, she particularly recommends __[Bahía Vik](bahiavik.com)__ in José Ignacio, Uruguay, the latest property from art collectors/ hoteliers Alex and Carrie Vik. “The beach bungalows are perched on the dunes of Mansa Beach.” Another favorite: __[Vira Vira](hotelviravira.com)__, in Chile’s Lake District, where private villa suites overlook the Liucura River. 

Tom Marchant, co-founder of the luxury travel agency __[Black Tomato](blacktomato.com)__, says that a hassle-free flight starts a trip off on the right foot. “Iceland is easy to get to from both coasts, plus it’s chic and stylish and has a stunning landscape,” he says. His clients always rave about the __[Hótel Rangá](hotelranga.is)__, an hour’s drive from Reykjavík. You can see the East Rangá River and Mount Hekla— without leaving your bed.

*For more romantic travel ideas, check out our [Romantic Getaway Guide](https://cnt.conde.io/reports/special-report-romantic-getaway-guide).*
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: The Best Way to Book a Last-Minute Valentine's Day Trip
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Custom travel specialist Henrietta Loyd says she can turn an itinerary around in 48 hours. Here's how.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: The Best Way to Book a Last-Minute Valentine's Day Trip

shortLinksItems.dek: When you surprise your spouse (and leave the kids at home), you can’t not have a good time.
shortLinksItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54cfe2989abb8d533165d3d2]||||||


Like most couples, MSNBC host JJ Ramberg and her architect husband, Scott Glass, have little time to take a vacation, let alone plan one. But unlike most couples, they don’t let such pressures stand in the way of getting out of town. Every year, they take turns plotting a week-long, no-kids trip—choosing the destination, booking the hotels, coordinating transportation, making dinner reservations, planning excursions—while never once letting on to the other where they’re going. Last year, Ramberg’s husband told her to “pack rain gear, hiking boots, and one nice thing for dinner,” she says. “When we got to the airport, I slid my passport into the machine and it said *Glasgow.* I’d never in a thousand years pick Scotland on my own, but it turned out to be one of my favorite trips ever.” The year before, she chose Morocco and a stay at [Kasbah du Toubkal](http://www.kasbahtoubkal.com/), a 14-room guesthouse in the foothills of the High Atlas Mountains.

“The key is to plan the trip *you* want to take, not the one you think your spouse wants to take,” she says. “Scott loves surfing, but he’d put together a much better surf trip than I would.” A good rule to abide by is: If you’ll love it, assume your partner will too. “Keep an open mind and it’ll be exciting,” she says. “Scott told the kids about Scotland, so they were in on it—and champing at the bit to tell me. But they didn’t. They kept his secret, and it was awesome.”

*For more romantic travel ideas, check out our [Romantic Getaway Guide](https://cnt.conde.io/reports/special-report-romantic-getaway-guide).*
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: When you surprise your spouse (and leave the kids at home), you can’t not have a good time.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: When you surprise your spouse (and leave the kids at home), you can’t not have a good time.

fields.name: Lauren DeCarlo
fields.shortBio: Lauren DeCarlo is the Articles Editor at Conde Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Before joining *Traveler*, Lauren was a freelance writer and editor. Her work has appeared in *New York* Magazine, ElleDecor.com, *Lucky*, and *WWD* among other publications.

shortLinksItems.dek: What's more romantic than a getaway for two? Here are some clever tips for making it happen.
shortLinksItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53da4f6fdcd5888e145ad093]||||||





##PERMISSION TO DAY-DRINK

Caroline Campion of the cooking site [devilandegg.com](devilandegg.com) was treated to a surprise trip to Charleston by her husband. “We spent an afternoon at the Pavilion Bar in the [Market Pavilion Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/charleston/market-pavilion-hotel--charleston), drinking bourbon cocktails with a couple we’d just met,” she says. “We’d normally never do that, and we’ll never see them again, but for 24 hours they were our best friends. There are certain cities that let you just be, and this is one.”

##THE PLAN IS NO PLAN

In every couple, there’s always a designated planner. One example is Christine Amorose of the lifestyle blog [cestchristine.com](cestchristine.com). But for a recent trip to the Dominican Republic with her boyfriend, the only thing she booked in advance was the hotel. No restaurants, no activities—just four nights at [Casa Bonita in Barahona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/baharona/casa-bonita-tropical-lodge). “It was sort of spontaneous, which took the pressure off me,” she says. “We were in it together.”

##REWRITE THE SCRIPT

When writer Ashlea Halpern’s boyfriend said he wanted clothes for his birthday, her initial thought was, *Boring!* But then she got to work on his real present. “I asked an art director friend to design a faux Topman gift card for $500, but I rewrote the fine print to say that it was redeemable at one specific Topman—the one in Prague, which I had booked a secret trip to,” she says. (And yes, he actually went to the Prague Topman.)

##SPLURGE ON YOUR HOTEL

You’ll probably spend more time in the room when it’s just the two of you, so book one you’d want to sleep until noon in. The private *maisons* at [Auberge du Soleil in Napa Valley](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/st-helena/auberge-du-soleil--napa-valley) overlook the hills of wine country and come with a terrace, a fireplace, and a steam shower (for two, of course). On the East Coast, you won’t do better than the turret suite at the Castle Hill Inn in Newport, Rhode Island. The cozy, wood-paneled, bi-level suite has panoramic ocean views.

##MAKE YOUR BUSINESS TRIP DO DOUBLE DUTY

Wherever interior designer Maca Huneeus and her vintner husband’s work takes them, they plot a trip to the most exotic place they can travel to easily—and quickly (they have four children back home). When her husband had to attend Vinexpo in Bordeaux, they used it as the jumping-off point for four nights at [La Maison Arabe](http://www.lamaisonarabe.com/) in Marrakech. “The more remote the place, the more bonding you do,” she says. “We’re in major cities all the time and know them so well. The unknown is much more romantic.” For L.A.–based photographer Dewey Nicks, however, getting away is less about place than a state of mind: “We tack shorter trips in the U.S. onto assignments and leave the kids with their grandparents.” And while it’s not Marrakech, it’s still romantic. “It’s nice to have a great dinner and stay in a hotel with your wife,” he says. “That and no jet lag make for a really good vacation.”

*For more romantic travel ideas, check out our [Romantic Getaway Guide](https://cnt.conde.io/reports/special-report-romantic-getaway-guide).*
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: What's more romantic than a getaway for two? Here are some clever tips for making it happen.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: What's more romantic than a getaway for two? Here are some clever tips for making it happen.

featureContentItems.hed: Well Traveled: Shiseido CEO Heidi Manheimer Loves Airplane Food (Sometimes)
featureContentItems.dek: The cosmetics exec reveals her favorite things about traveling, including her most beloved destinations.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d243659abb8d533165ee3a]||||||

Heidi Manheimer is coming up on her 15th year as CEO of Shiseido Cosmetics America, and in that time she’s flown nearly 2 million miles, mastered the art of packing (it involves those plastic covers you get at dry cleaners), and has been able to find the best blow-out even when she’s far from home. Here, Manheimer fills *Condé Nast Traveler* in on her travel routines, her favorite destinations, and how to avoid looking jet-lagged (spoiler: it involves Shiseido products).

__How often are you on the road?__ 

At least twice a month. I typically fly between 75,000 to 125,000 miles a year.

__Favorite travel haunts?__ 

I always stay at the [Conrad Tokyo](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/japan/hibiyakoen/conrad-tokyo) on business. For shopping, I love [Plain People](http://www.one-be-one.com/stores.html) for their comfortable, easy-to-pack clothes.


__Favorite restaurants?__ 

In Tokyo, Nodoguroya for the whole grilled sea bass and the sea bass sashimi, and Soba Yoshida for the zarusoba (cold soba) and tamagoyaki (cooked eggs).

__What's your night-before-a-biz-trip routine?__ 

I pack, reusing the plastic covers from the dry cleaners to wrap my clothes in so nothing gets wrinkled. I bring a lot of Derek Lam, Brunello Cucinelli, and Etro tops that transition well with black pants from day to night.


__What is your morning ritual?__ 

I always pack my own breakfast: two hard-boiled eggs, Laughing Cow cheese, Justin’s travel-sized almond butter, and dried ginger to help with digestion.

__Preferred carry-on?__ 

[Burton Wheelie Flight Deck Travel Bag](http://www.burton.com/default/wheelie-flight-deck-travel-bag/F15-116081.html?q=wheelie%20flight) because it has a ton of compartments.

__What do you wear in-transit?__ 

I always travel in something comfortable like jeans and a soft shirt or fleece. And I always bring along a J. Crew cashmere cardigan. I typically wear Marni flats or Prada slip-on sneakers—never high heels in an airport in case I need to make a run for it.


__What do you do on a flight?__ 

I like to sleep as much as I can. En route to Tokyo, you can do it all—read, sleep, work, and drink. Longer flights are sometimes easier to handle.

__Is there something you'd never do on a flight?__ 

I never eat airplane bread, so I always bring a little bag of Finn Crisps to keep me happy.

__Favorite business cabin?__ 

ANA. It’s quiet and the service is terrific. There’s always someone around if you need them, but they’re not intrusive. I love eating Japanese food en route to Tokyo, and they offer great meals.

__What loyalty programs do you belong to?__ 

I try to stay true to United—which is tied-in with ANA—and I’m part of their Global Services program. I also have Executive Platinum status on American Airlines—tied-in with British Airways—which we frequently use for personal travel.

__Favorite airport?__ 

Heathrow. It has great shops, food, and bookstores.

__Favorite airport lounge?__ 

British Airways at Heathrow.

__How could travelers travel better?__

Do your best to stick to one airline and get status. Check your ticket very carefully to ensure that your name is spelled properly so you can be pre-checked, which will save you a lot of time. Always pre-select your seat prior. I personally like to sit as close to the front as possible—and on an aisle.

__Preferred smartphone?__ 

iPhone 6. I use AT&T.

__What apps do you use most frequently on the road?__ 

I use [Beautified](https://www.getbeautified.com/) when I’m looking for a quick treatment or blow-out, and I’m a huge Uber fan.

__What do you do as soon as you get to your hotel room?__ 

More than 50 percent of the time I switch my room: It could be anything from wanting a different layout to the overall vibe. I don’t want to be near an elevator or hear doors banging. Then I immediately unpack.

__How do you keep from looking jet-lagged?__ 

I pack single-use face masks—either the [Shiseido Benefiance Retinol Eye Mask](http://www.shiseido.com/benefiance-wrinkleresist24-pure-retinol-express-smoothing-eye-mask-3pc-set/0730852929203,en_US,pd.html?gclid=CJ_36saZo8MCFUwS7AodV0QAcA) or the [Clé de Peau Beauté Intensive Brightening Mask](http://www.cledepeaubeaute.com/intensive-brightening-mask/9990000000115.html?dwvar_9990000000115_size=6pairs#start=1&cgid=skincare-categories-masks-massage) and always apply one the first night I’m abroad.

__Are you a fan of room service?__  

I’ll do it every now and then. If I have an early morning conference call I might order-in breakfast but generally I prefer to go to restaurants.

featureContentItems.hed: Morning News: Singapore Airlines Announces Premium Economy Seats That Look Absolutely Fantastic
featureContentItems.dek: Singapore’s new offering will improve the lives of long-haul fliers willing to pay a little more for a much more comfortable trip.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Morning News: Singapore Airlines Announces Premium Economy Seats That
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Singapore’s new offering will improve the lives of long-haul fliers willing to pay a little more for a much more comfortable trip.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Morning News: Singapore Airlines Announces Premium Economy Seats That Look Absolutely Fantastic
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Singapore’s new offering will improve the lives of long-haul fliers willing to pay a little more for a much more comfortable trip.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d23dddc335146e49866e62]||||||





Singapore Airlines will launch a new premium economy cabin on August 9 because, they say, “at 30,000 feet, you should be living it up.” Seats will have 38 inches of pitch, recline eight inches, and come with two USB plugs, a universal power plug, “Wi-Fi connectivity,” and 13-inch TV screens. Premium economy passengers will also get priority check in and boarding. The service, writes Gary Leff, will be “of definite interest to those in the U.S. with Chase, Citibank, American Express, and Starwood points and who are looking to both stretch those points for the most travel and avoid flying long-haul economy.” ([Singapore](http://siapremiumeconomy.com/) and [Boarding Area](http://viewfromthewing.boardingarea.com/2015/02/03/revealed-singapore-airlines-new-premium-economy-offers-pre-order-meals-champagne/))

All-business-class airline La Compagnie will start flying between Newark Liberty and London Luton Airport on April 24, after [rumors it could start service as early as March](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-02-03/morning-news-a-new-way-to-fly-to-london). The airline flies specially outfitted 74-seat 757s, with seats reminiscent of domestic first-class cabins. La Compagnie is offering some dates for as little as $1,007 round trip, a price that beats some economy-class tickets for flights in May. Service will start with four flights weekly, increasing to six a week, the carrier says. (For more on the airline, see [Barbara Peterson’s August report on La Compagnie](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-08/two-new-transatlantic-flight-options).) ([La Compagnie](https://www.lacompagnie.com/en))

A TransAsia plane carrying 58 people crashed in Taipei, killing at least 22 on board. The ATR 72 can be seen seen in dramatic dash cam footage striking a vehicle on a highway before crashing into the Keelung River. The crash will likely prompt even more questions about the relative safety of aviation in Asia. ([AP](http://skift.com/2015/02/04/transasia-plane-crashes-in-taipei-shortly-after-takeoff/))

Emirates is the world’s best airline overall for business travel, say *Condé Nast Traveler* readers. Other top choices include Qatar Airways, Virgin America, and Virgin Atlantic. Barbara Peterson has more details on why the top ten are so popular. ([Condé Nast Traveler](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-02-03/worlds-best-airlines-business-travel-readers-choice-awards-2014))

The Patriots celebrate their Super Bowl win with a parade today in Boston, and Caitlin Morton has the details on where to watch. ([Condé Nast Traveler](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-02-03/where-to-watch-the-patriots-super-bowl-parade-in-boston))

"Virgin Galactic's manufacturing crew is about two-thirds done with building a new spacecraft," Susan Montoya Bryan reports, "and the operations team is ramping up for a test-flight program that will serve as one of the last major hurdles to getting off the ground." The new progress comes after a fatal crash of Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo in October 2014. ([AP](http://bigstory.ap.org/article/25d1cab6e71c4fd5b5a146b7d80c1334/virgin-galactic-gets-back-track-toward-space-tourism))

fields.name: Paul Brady
fields.shortBio: Paul Brady is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s consumer news editor.
fields.bio: Paul Brady is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s consumer news editor, with a focus on the strategies that help consumers have better trips. He has been covering the travel industry for nearly 10 years, at *Condé Nast Traveler*, The Huffington Post, *Budget Travel*, and other outlets. He graduated from the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University.

featureContentItems.hed: Morning News: A New Way to Fly to London?
featureContentItems.dek: The all-business-class airline La Compagnie may soon launch service to London, giving travelers a comfortable new way to cross the Atlantic.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: La Compagnie: A New Way to Fly to London?
featureContentItems.seoDescription: The all-business-class airline La Compagnie that currently only flies between New York and Paris may soon launch service to London, giving travelers a comfortable new way to cross the Atlantic.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Morning News: A New Way to Fly to London?
featureContentItems.socialDescription: The all-business-class airline La Compagnie that currently only flies between New York and Paris may soon launch service to London, giving travelers a comfortable new way to cross the Atlantic.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2f29cdddaa35c30f6607f]||||||





All-business-class airline La Compagnie may announce today service between Newark and London Luton Airport. Currently, it only flies between Newark and Charles de Gaulle, with a 74-seat cabin that appeals to “budget-minded business fliers and vacationers seeking an upscale experience at an affordable price,” as [Barbara Peterson reported last summer](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-08/two-new-transatlantic-flight-options). Reservations for London could open today, with flights to start before the end of March, according to an email from the carrier seen by Routes Online. (__Update, Feb. 4:__ [La Compagnie will in fact launch its new service on April 24](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-02-04/morning-news-singapore-airlines-announces-premium-economy-seats-that-look-absolutely-fantastic).) It joins other upstarts—Norwegian, Wow Air—in expanding customer choice across the Atlantic, though La Compagnie’s cabin experience is considerably different than most of the competition. ([Routes Online](http://www.routesonline.com/news/29/breaking-news/246982/la-compagnie-set-to-select-luton-for-new-london-newark-route/) and [Condé Nast Traveler](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-08/two-new-transatlantic-flight-options))

Bloomberg reports that Google, which is openly working on driverless cars, could mount a serious challenge to Uber, after testing “what appears to be a Google ride-sharing app that is currently being used by Google employees.” ([Bloomberg](http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-02-02/exclusive-google-and-uber-are-going-to-war-over-taxis))

Newly released renderings of the Carnival Vista, which will launch in 2016, make the ship look less [JFK-in-Newport](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-02-02/morning-news-thousands-of-flights-canceled-as-latest-winter-storm-hits-midwest-northeast) and more “BlueIguana Tequila Bar.” ([USA Today](http://www.usatoday.com/picture-gallery/travel/cruises/2015/01/23/first-look-at-carnivals-next-ship-the-carnival-vista/22209019/))

Today will be a significantly easier day for air travel than Monday, with only hundreds of weather-related cancellations compared to thousands yesterday. ([USA Today](http://www.usatoday.com/story/todayinthesky/2015/02/03/tuesdays-air-travel-outlook-better-so-far-/22786583/))

A report from Kayak analyzing more than a billion search queries reveals some surprising trends about the way we’ll travel in 2015. ([Condé Nast Traveler](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-02-02/what-a-billion-kayak-searches-reveal-about-the-way-we-ll-travel-in-2015))

Blade, the helicopter charter app, confirms that it has added airport transfers to its offerings, which also include trips to the Hamptons and the Mohegan Sun casino resort in Connecticut. Trips cost $800 total, with room for up to six passengers, to JFK, LaGuardia, Newark, and Teterboro. ([Blade](http://www.flyblade.com/))

American Airlines has created heritage amenity kits that take design cues from the carriers that preceded it, among them Allegheny, American West, Piedmont, and TWA. The AP’s Scott Mayerowitz rightly mentions the kits with an “#Avgeek alert,” and American encourages passengers to post their earliest memories of flying one of the carriers with an #OurHeritage hashtag. The new business- and first-class amenity kits, to be available through January 2016, will include Red Flower toiletries. ([American Airlines](http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/american-airlines-continues-investment-in-customer-experience-with-refreshed-collectors-item-amenity-kits-300029896.html) and [Twitter](https://twitter.com/GlobeTrotScott/status/562317506359345152))

These are the world’s best hotels for business, according to Condé Nast Traveler readers. ([Condé Nast Traveler](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-02-02/top-10-u-s-hotels-for-business-travelers-readers-choice-awards-2014))

Geoffrey Kent describes the founding of Abercrombie & Kent, the trend-setting luxury travel company, and makes some predictions about the future of the travel industry in an interview with Samantha Shankman. ([Skift](http://skift.com/2015/02/02/interview-abercrombie-kent-ceo-on-inventing-experiential-travel/))

What’s it like to travel to Saudi Arabia as a female business traveler? Joe Sharkey interviews one to find out. ([NYT](http://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/03/business/international/businesswomen-navigate-traditions-in-saudi-arabia.html))

The cruise line Ponant shot some impressive drone footage of its 132-stateroom ship Le Soléal on a recent trip through the Adriatic. ([YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h4W-sGE3-C0))

Was news last week: Google updated its Now app for Android users to better integrate with travel apps like Airbnb, Kayak, Lyft, and TripAdvisor. Now was already quite useful for flight tracking, and that functionality remains. ([Google](http://insidesearch.blogspot.com/2015/01/google-app-update-get-now-cards-from.html))

fields.name: Paul Brady
fields.shortBio: Paul Brady is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s consumer news editor.
fields.bio: Paul Brady is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s consumer news editor, with a focus on the strategies that help consumers have better trips. He has been covering the travel industry for nearly 10 years, at *Condé Nast Traveler*, The Huffington Post, *Budget Travel*, and other outlets. He graduated from the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University.

featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53db1bc46dec627b14a199c9]||||||


Attention, moms of energetic young boys and water slide fanatics of all ages: Here's another travel deal I might just nab myself if I weren't headed to Europe on business: Through December 18 [Atlantis](http://www.atlantisbahamas.com), on Paradise Island in the Bahamas, is charging $299 per adult for three nights' accommodations, which includes four days' use of the over-the-top water park (complete with phenomenal water playground for toddlers) and entrance to the 50,000-creature marine habitat (which had my kids mesmerized when we were there last March; pictured at left is my four-year-old, who now wants to grow up to be a scuba diver). Included with each room are two shallow-water dolphin experiences at the resort's renowned and eco-friendly Dolphin Cay. Even when you add in all the mandatory taxes and fees, plus the $198 air fare from New York or $178 fare from Boston on JetBlue, this deal still works out to be a good value IF you can travel on the requisite days of the week (spelled out in the fine print). The deal is for travel through December 21. Three key tips, based on my family's visit to Atlantis last March:

[#image: /photos/53db1bc4dcd5888e145e4594]||||||

*It's a mammoth resort with five hotels. The $299 rate is for the Beach Tower, which is the least expensive and most dated in terms of decor and amenities. If it were me, I might pay slightly more to stay in theCoral Towers, which are more centrally located and, depending on your children's ages, might represent the best combo of kid-friendly and affordable. For kid-friendly_ luxury,_ plus the prettiest views and a gorgeous beach to yourself, choose The Reef. If you're kidless and want plush seclusion, splurge on The Cove, which at $599 for the package price is a steal.

*Food and drinks at the restaurants and snack bars are _insanely_ expensive. You can save by going to the marina store and stocking up on provisions there. Or you can buy a dining plan. If it were me, I'd purchase the casual dining plan--which costs about $350 for breakfast and dinner daily for a family of four for the four days--and I'd save on lunch and snack expenses by hitting the store. If you opt to stay in the condos that comprise The Reef, you can save by buying food in the store off the lobby and cooking it in your kitchenette.





*The weather can be a bit breezy in December, but even if the ocean is too cold, the pools should be warm enough. For surer weather, wait till February or March. According to the hotel industry analysts I've been interviewing for my upcoming January _Perrin Report_, the deals will be _even better_ in the new year.

fields.name: Wendy Perrin
fields.bio: Wendy is the founder and editor of [WendyPerrin.com](http://www.wendyperrin.com/).  She is also TripAdvisor’s first-ever Travel Advocate, sharing her advice with TripAdvisor’s visitors.  Formerly, as *Condé Nast Traveler*’s Director of Consumer News and Digital Community, Wendy wrote the magazine’s travel advice column The Perrin Report for 17 years, The Perrin Post blog for eight years, and The Perrin Postcard newsletter for four years. She started out long ago as the magazine’s Ombudsman, investigating reader complaints about travel companies and helping wronged travelers get compensation, and that led to her book *Wendy Perrin’s Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know* (Fodor’s).

featureContentItems.body:
## Sybarites of the Caribbean: 10 New Spas and Treatments Worth the Trip
[#image: /photos/53ea8e83976f8f2d44d55c21]||||||

**BAHAMAS**



 **Mandara Spa at the Atlantis Resort, Paradise Island**



 Exhaustive offerings even include a menu for teens. Come early for a dip in the marble whirlpool before indulging in the Elemis Exotic Lime and Ginger Salt Glow ($175), a body scrub followed by a 50-minute massage ([http://www.atlantisbahamas.com](http://www.atlantisbahamas.com)); 242-363-2000).

 **TURKS AND CAICOS**



 **Spa at the Regent Palms**



 Mediterranean and Caribbean elements mix at this hip getaway. The Mother of Pearl Body Exfoliator ($85) lasts 30 minutes and uses crushed conch shell and aromatherapy oil ([regentpalms.com](http://regentpalms.com); 649-946-8666).

 **JAMAICA**



 **Rockhouse**



 This charming Negril resort has a palapa built over the water for massages. The Rhassoul Mud Wrap ($90) uses ginger and clove along with rhassoul mud to soothe sore muscles ([rockhousehotel.com](http://rockhousehotel.com); 876-957-4373).

 **Fern Tree at Half Moon Resort**



 Inside this 68,000-square-foot expanse, even the manicure ($30) gets with the island theme, beginning with an aromatherapy soak and scrub using herbs developed by a native "spa elder," then a firm relaxing massage and a splash of rum to invigorate ([halfmoon.com](http://halfmoon.com); 878-953-2211).

 **ANTIGUA**



 **Spa at Curtain Bluff**



 Five treatment rooms sit seaside in this white-shuttered Spanish colonial-style getaway. The Green Coffee Wrap ($120) gently exfoliates, then lets guests sweat out the toxins believed to trap fatty deposits subcutaneously ([curtainbluff.com](http://curtainbluff.com); 268-462-8400).

 **Spa Tranquility, Verandah Resort & Spa**



 This 30-acre waterfront property hews to green principles. The spa's Luminous "C" and Sea facial ($125) uses vitamin C and powdered freeze-dried seaweed in a rejuvenating, glow-inducing session ([verandahresortandspa.com](http://verandahresortandspa.com); 268-562-6845).

 **Hermitage Bay**



 Amid 25 cottages dotted along a hidden cove, this pocket-size spa has great views of the sea. The Sun Soothers Wrap ($90) is the must-have treatment in case of sunburn: aloe, cucumber, and oil are applied to the skin ([hermitagebay.com](http://hermitagebay.com); 268-562-5500).

 **SINT MAARTEN**



 **Dior Spa at the Cliff at Cupecoy Beach**



 This three-room spa has a cliffside home overlooking white-sand Cupecoy Beach, so its French balneotherapy bath additives such as seawater, seaweed, and sea salt are especially apropos ([diorspa-stmaarten.com](http://diorspa-stmaarten.com); 599-546-6620).

 **ST. LUCIA**



 **The Landings**



 Papaya and pineapple are the body scrub ingredients nonpareil in this eight-room center of indulgence. The 30-minute St. Lucian Polish ($85) exfoliates so that vacation tans last longer ([landings.rockresorts.com](http://landings.rockresorts.com); 877-657-7625).

 **Jade Mountain**



 A dozen massages can be done in this new spa complex of 28 suites, most with infinity pools and panoramic views of the Pitons from a hill above classic Anse Chastanet resort. We like the Menage-a-Spa ($210), in which three therapists simultaneously perform a manicure, pedicure, and facial ([jademountainstlucia.com](http://jademountainstlucia.com); 758-459-4000).

featureContentItems.hed: Where to Watch the Patriots' Super Bowl Parade in Boston
featureContentItems.dek: There aren’t many reasons to watch a parade during a massive blizzard, but a Super Bowl win might just be the ultimate excuse.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Where to Watch the Patriots' Super Bowl Parade in Boston
featureContentItems.seoDescription: There aren’t many reasons to watch a parade during a massive blizzard, but a Super Bowl win might just be the ultimate excuse.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Where to Watch the Patriots' Super Bowl Parade in Boston
featureContentItems.socialDescription: There aren’t many reasons to watch a parade during a massive blizzard, but a Super Bowl win might just be the ultimate excuse.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d11cebc335146e498664f7]||||||


New England defeated Seattle during Sunday’s Super Bowl, which means Patriots fans will be partying for the next year (or three). But the ultimate celebration will be the Super Bowl parade, an NFL tradition that takes place each year in the winning team’s hometown. 

The festivities start on 11 a.m. on Wednesday, with the route leading from Prudential Tower to City Hall (view a map [here](http://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2015/02/02/map-parade-route-boston-for-patriots/XoPoYqWz6xDeFaEIevqP8J/story.html)). The parade had originally been scheduled to take place Tuesday, but had to get postponed a day due to a major snowstorm in Boston. But the show must and will go on, lest we face an entire city of irate football fans. If you are willing to brave the weather, here are the best places to view the parade with your fellow Patriots devotees.

Use the map below to plot your course:


[#iframe: https://mapsengine.google.com/map/u/0/embed?mid=zo-EXJg0INfg.kqeyzkKqWXEE](600x450)||||||

[Boston Common](http://www.cityofboston.gov/freedomtrail/bostoncommon.asp)  
(617) 635-4505

(617) 635-4505

(617) 536-6300

(617) 267-4000

725 Boylston St.  
(617) 859-8181

fields.name: Caitlin Morton
fields.shortBio: Caitlin Morton is the Editorial Coordinator at Condé Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Caitlin Morton has been working at Condé Nast Traveler since July 2014. She enjoys baked goods, Ireland, orange nail polish, and words. One time she held the door open for Ian McKellen, which is as close to fame as she will ever get.
